author: bogeyface

description.text:
This is a variation of Triffid Hunter's E-steps fine tuning suggestions.

  1. Slice at 95% (rectilinear) infill.
  2. Print and then abort the print once only the taller section is printing.
  3. Compare top infill (100%), and infill (95%).
    • If the top infill has gaps between the lines, increase E-steps by 0.5%-1%.
    • If the 95% infill does not have gaps, reduce E-steps by 2%.
  4. Repeat from 2.

Infill:

95%

title: LiPo 2s 2200mAh battery case for Tamiya RC Cars

description.text:
Remix of LANEBoysRC LiPo case for Tamiya TL-01B chassis. This chassis is used with Baja King & Baja Champ. The case allows for the use of a 2S 2200mAh Turnigy (designed around larger 30-40C discharge model but 20-30C will also fit as it is slightly narrower) battery in a 3D printed shell that fits into the original oval NiMH space. The balance plug can tucked into the cavity within the lid so that it doesn't get damaged.

This battery holder will also be suitable for other Tamiya models where you are converting to LiPo such as TL-01, TA-01, DF-02. The off-the-shelf round LiPo's don't fit into the older Tamiya models as they are approximately 5mm too long and this design allows for upgrade while still working with older chassis dimensions. LiPo battery significantly improves the performance of the car and it well worthwhile upgrading.

Version 2 (Updated with end cap design)
This version has the case printing vertically to improve print quality and used a tight sliding fit end cap to secure the battery. This version is a much neater solution and doesn't require any screws to hold together. It may be necessary to very lightly sand the lip where the two parts slide together but it is designed to be a tight fit so it doesn't come apart during use. The updated OpenSCAD script is included.

Version 1 (Original with two halves)
The case dimensions have been modified to fit a Turnigy 2s 2200 LiPo battery along with additional cutouts to the case to reduce weight and total printing time. The screw holes have also been adjusted to allow an M3 screw to be threaded in by hand rather than using a threaded insert. Print the case in two halves and then screw together with battery in place. The modified OpenSCAD script with the changes is included.

Have yet to mount it but initial test fit seems promising. I made this so I can make an adapter for a 5" chuck on the lathe I am making the adapter for. It should also serve as a good template for drilling the holes in the 5" chuck adapter. Hoping it will allow me to drill a center hole so I can get a bore hole and turn between centers using my stock Harbor Freight 3" chuck.

I would print with at least 30-50% infill with layers 0.2mm or under for good adhesion. Just be sure the first layer really sticks as it will impact the runout greatly. Consider adding a few solid layers to top and bottom so you can face off some material once mounted to ensure low runout.

description.text:
This is a low-friction spool holder for the Makergear M2.

I made it as an addition to the awesome elevated spool holder by slipshine:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37210

I was having trouble with Ninjaflex & Polyflex not extruding properly, and having adjusted every setting under the sun, I finally realised that the tension on the filament (as the extruder was trying to pull upwards on the half-kilo spool, which was on a standard side-mounted spool holder) was too great nad the flexible filaments weren't feeding properly. I figured an elevated spool holder might fix this. But I also wanted to take it 1 step further and remove as much friction as possible.

So I designed a cylinder that fits standard skateboard bearings (22mm diameter), with a flange on each end to stop the spool slipping off. I mounted it using 2mm thick PLA washers (files included), 1/4 inch threaded rod & 1/4-inch lock nuts x 4.

The cylinder can be printed vertically, but be aware there is some overhang. I manually added some supports in Simplify 3D. I printed it in PLA, 40% infill and it's definitely strong enough to hold a half or 1kg spool.

To assemble just insert one bearing into each end of the cylinder, slide it on to the threaded rod, thread a washer on next, and fix it in the middle with 1/4-inch lock nuts. Tighten the lock nuts until the spool spins freely but doesn't rattle.

I then just placed it across the top of the vertical mounts from slipshine's spool holder which I'd already printed and attached to the side of my printer. To prevent the whole thing sliding off I just added another washer and lock nut on each end.

It's a very low-friction spool holder that so far works really well. The only downside is if there's a sudden lurch of the hotend to the right with a sudden stop, the momentum can cause the spool to continue rolling & feeding out filament , but so far hasn't caused any tangles.

This is version 1.0 I may update it

title: Quick and dirty curtain hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Why

Because I could. It was quicker than ordering some on-line & about the same as going to the shop. Plus I wanted to see if I could do it quickly without learning how to model complex shapes.

How

An existing curtain hook was scanned on a 2D flatbed scanner. The image was tidied up and thresholded. The image was then imported into Windows 10's 3D Builder app (Inert>Add>Load Image, Contour, no smoothing, textures off, inverse off), resized, saved as an stl then printed (PLA 100% fill).

title: Model railroad, set of bents (supports) for a custom trestle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a set of bents from my trestle design. I used the HO trestle design and built bents with heights from 15-mm to 90-mm. The top width of all of the bents is 40 mm. The bottom width is determined by the height, beam angle and top width. For O or S scale, you'll probably want to scale up by somewhere around 150%. For N or Z, scale by about 70%.

This is a set of bents (supports) for a model railroad trestle. I took some liberties in the design to make printing easier. This bent design is same as my trestle except that I removed the fillets I had put in the trestle design to facilitate printing. The top width is 40-mm (a little bigger than what you need for HO). Heights range from 15-mm to 90-mm every 5-mm. Parts list: None. Assembly instructions: One angle beam is already attached. The opposite angle beam is printed separately and you can glue it to the assembly if desired (it looks OK without it). Printing Instructions: The bents were printed on a Makerbot Replicator2
  • PLA (Makerbot filament)
  • Printed: Low(faster) resolution, 5% infill, 2 shells, 0.30 mm layer height, 230C
    • This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by the Free Software Foundation; either version 3 of the License, LGPL version 2.1, or (at your option) any later version of the GPL. see http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-2.0.html Woverine Boat LLC is providing this document and its contents on an "as is" basis and makes no representations or warranties of any kind with respect to this communication or its contents. Woverine Boat LLC disclaims all such representations and warranties, including for example warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. Version number 14
    Author : Wolverine Boat, LCC - [email protected]
    Copyright 2014 by Wolverine Boat, LCC
    Created March 1, 2014
    Modification:
    Feb 18, 2014 ... original version of trestle (ver #13)
    March 1, 2014 ... set of bents (design version #14)
    Special instructions:
    User feedback:
    Limitations:
    Designed with OpenSCAD 2013.06 Model train info (approximate values and may depend on manufacturer (1" equals 25.4 mm) O27 scale 1:48, track ~50.0-mm W x 10.3-mm H, typical car ~54.8-mm W x 79.3-mm H, car+track ~ 89.6 mm H, 1-ft = 6.4 mm S scale 1:64, track ~47.0-mm W x 13.6-mm H, typical box car 51.2-mm W x 67.8-mm H, car+track ~ 81.4-mm H, 1 ft=4.8 mm HO 1:87, track ~28.5-mm W x 4.6-mm H, typical box car 36.0-mm W x 55.8-mm H, car+track ~60.4-mm H, 1 ft=3.6 mm N 1:160, track ~16.0-mm W x 3.8-mm H, typical box car 20.3-mm W x 31.5-mm H, car+track ~ 35.3-mm H, 1 ft=1.9 mm Z 1:220, track ~16.0-mm W x 4.7-mm H, typical box car 15.6-mm W x 21.9-mm H, car+track ~ 26.6-mm H, 1 ft=1.4 mm (Lionel O track is 4.4-mm higher than O27 track). I have not listed G scale because it's too big for my designed parts. Disclaimer: This design was not based on a specific prototype and there isn't a true scale for this bent. The design is based loosely on Google images of various trestles around the world. Features and dimensions of real bridges were altered for the simplicity of the design and to make the bents more printable. Some best practices for printing:
  • optimize print parameters for your printer, filament, etc (only you can determine the best parameters)
  • use good filament
  • level your build plate prior to printing complex parts. it's worth the few minutes it takes. always level after removing tape, or if pulling hard to remove a part.
  • make sure the build plate is clean.
  • if using blue tape, stretch it tight when applying it to the build plate.
  • if you have small holes in the blue tape, the bents should still print without any problems, but the bent surface won't be smooth
  • pre-feed the filament 30 to 60-s before printing (i.e., run load for 30-60s)
  • do not print several complicated parts in one build (do complex parts by themselves)
  • I find that printing faster is better (probably so the filament can't ball up in one spot)
  • when the filament spool gets low, the filament can be tightly wound on the spool and the filament may not feed properly... take special care...
  • when a new spool is used, it is easy for the filament to jump outside the spool and then it will bind up later around the spool holder ruining your build
  • make sure it is easy for the filament to enter the filament feed tube. others have designed spools, mounts, etc. for that purpose. i use a small rope that forces the filament away from the spool before entering the filament feed tube.
  • if you hear clicking when printing, that may be a result of the filament wrapped around the spool and not feeding
  • make sure that there aren't any obstructions on the spool, such as some filament used to hold it in place during shipping
  • for the replicaor2, look at the blob a filament in the left front part of the build plate and then the trail of filament to the biuild location. there should be a glob, and the line of filament should be continuous and smooth
  • one way to remove parts when using blue tape is to use a very thin spatula bought in craft-art stores (advice from youtube). get one with a wide, blunt front end (not long and thin). mine is 11 mils thick (0.011") and 20-mm wide at the front. a painting spatula/scraper in hardware stores won't work and may damage the build plate. (I use blue tape so I don't have any best practices for bare plates, heated plates or for other tapes like mylar)
  • perform regular maintenance (grease, etc).
  • when I continued to have problems printing even after performing maintenance, following troublshooting instructions, changing filaments, cleaning gears, cleaning everything, optimizing print parameters, changing temperatures, etc., I bought a new extruder assembly from Makerbot and it solved all of my problems.

description.text:
This is a mashup of MikeyB's very popular Crossfire 2 and my own T4 Quadcopter's tubular arms which are a bit more rigid than the originals (see video here).
Please refer to MikeyB's quadcopter for excellent instructions and the other parts required.
Note: I'd recommend using a 4-in-1 ESC if you want to build this quadcopter. MikeyB's design uses separate ESCs strapped to each arm which is not possible with the tubular arms. A 4-in-1 ESC combines the ESCs with the power distribution board and can be mounted in the center of the frame - very tidy!
Oh, and the Sketchup file is included so you can make changes to suit yourself. Check out the whole "T" copter family:
  • TX8 Octocopter
  • T6 Hexacopter
  • T4 Quadcopter (10" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 315 (7-8" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 250 (5" props)
  • Tubular Crossfire 2 quadcopter
    • I've added a post on the forums over at DIY Drones for discussing and improving these designs.

28 March 2014
  • added the short "springy" leg STL from my T6 design. Here's a quick video that shows a longer version of the springy leg design (2nd half).

comments.text: Yep ABS is a real challenge.  This probably doesn't help but  I've been printing these kind of things with PLA and have never had a problem.  PLA will crack if it gets a big hit - but then ABS will bend and stretch (with less force) and once it's stretched it is usually throw-away too.  I've been flying on 30+degC (86degF) days and never had any issue with heat softening parts.  All up I'm a  PLA fan - especially for bigger parts.

I recently acquired a couple hundred 18650 lithium ion batteries and I needed a way to mount them for a couple different projects I’m prototyping.

Design requirements:
-No spot welding
-Minimal material needed for print
-Fast, easy print (preferably no supports needed)
-Single object (can be used for + or – side)
-Multiple solder points between adjacent cells for high and even current flow
-Small airgap between batteries for better cooling
-Very modular (can be used in either series or parallel configurations)
-No fine features (I like printing with large nozzles)
-Semi-permanent
-No costly hardware

I did not want to buy any springs because of the quantity needed. A Keystone 209 spring may only be 20 cents, but 400 of them would be more than I paid for all of my batteries. Instead I am using nickel tape (ebay: 7Meters long, 8mm wide, $2.29 total).
For parallel configurations I align all batteries in the same direction and weave 14cm of nickel tape through all of the slots. The ends of the metal tape are soldered to itself. This produces a 1s4p group. Multiple groups can then be soldered together for larger packs.

For serial configurations, the batteries are installed in alternating directions. The bottom bracket uses nickel tape to connect batteries 1 and 2 together, then another piece of nickel to connect batteries 3 and 4 together. The top bracket uses 3 pieces of nickel tape and only batteries 2 and 3 are connected to each other. 1 and 4 are the + and – terminals of the 4s1p configuration.

This is still a work in progress.

To do list:
-Add some sort of interlocking tab/key so parallel groups will slide/snap together
-Design more sizes (3, 5, 6, 7, and 8)
-Design an external cover (or snap-on case) for larger battery packs.

Custom built

No

No

PETG
0.6mm Nozzle
0.4mm layer height

remixed_from.title: P3Steel / I3 - E3d V6 Dual hot end mount with channelled cold end cooling flow

title: Tronxy X3 - E3d V6 Dual hot end mount with channeled cold end cooling

description.text:
Update: I forgot the cutout for the lower wheel screw of the X carriage. Fixed now, sorry for that.

This is a remix of the great hot end mount made by jbabio. I modified it for the Tronxy X3.
It is only the back part, you need the front part from the original.

I made this, because all current E3D V6 mounts for the Tronxy X3 make it nearly impossible to print ABS. The air from the cooling fan of the E3D will be reflected by the mounts to the heat bed. That lets the ABS curl.

Be aware that I didn't print it till now. So I am not 100% sure that the parts will match.
I couldn't change the original STL file directly, because OpenSCAD has problems with it.
So I redesigned it from scratch with OpenSCAD. SCAD file is provided.

I tried hard to get the original dimensions from the original STL file, so I hope it will fit.
The air outlets are a little bit different, but that should make no problems with mounting it.
I didn't use the nut catches, because I want to use M3 heat inserts instead.

description.text:
This is an ice pack holder for your freezer. It is designed to separate the "slim" lunch box ice packs so that more surface area is exposed to air and you can freeze them faster than if they were all in a big stack. Each "spot" is 17mm wide with a 3mm thick separator. Some of the icepacks will lean and touch a bit, but you should see an improvement in freezing performance. If you are careful to stack them all in the same orientation, they should be able to stay fully separate.

I have included a full 8 pack version, an 8 pack version with base slots to reduce material use (and add more surface area for air to make contact?), and a 4 pack version with the cutouts.

Designed specifically for these: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003FO2B5U/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I have to freeze 8 packs at a time for a homebrewing setup, so I designed this thing. It seems to help.

title: Fixed Torque Wrench Handles from 0.5Nm to 6Nm (in half and 1Nm steps)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update Nov26., 2017:
Published my Torque Measuring Lever (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2670493) to easily test the parts with a simple scale. :)

Update Nov 23., 2017:
Added 4.0Nm, 5.0Nm and 6.0Nm cases and rotors. More than about 3Nm is not possible without the bit holder is glued into the rotor, otherwise it would slip. 3Nm means about 100 kg on the edge of the plastic hexagon. I used 2 component epoxy because PETG does not work well with all adhesives. A ¼" magnet bit holder costs about $4, the easy holder with a square less than $2. See pictures. By the way: 6Nm then slowly becomes uncomfortable for the hand. :)

Update Nov 7th, 2017:
Added 0.5Nm case and rotor, added new 1.0Nm and renamed existing to 0.8Nm (was a bit to low in PETG).

Low torques are necessary for many applications, such as carbon parts on mountain bikes or screw connections on electronic and robotic devices. But the usual torque wrenches works reliably only at 4 or 5 Newton meters and above.

Fixed torque handles are available, but always for a high price tag ($100-200). This is why a set of 1/4 "drives with low, fixed torque for self-printing becomes handy. Inspired by a NozzleTorqueDrive from Anders Olsson (I like the design), my parts have a larger diameter with more and thicker fins and the housing is screwed. Through a continuous 1/4 "slot all common inserts can be used and even left-hand crews can be used by placing the insert on the bottom.

The case dimensions are the same for all drives and differ only in the engraved torque values. The screwed cap is also the same for all drives. There is a version with slightly more play if print quality affects the thread. The nut value is 19mm or ¾", very common in most countries. Please do not tighten too much; otherwise, the housing may break!

The rotors receive the different tripping torques by different thicknesses of the fins (main feature) and by different lengths in the vertical axis (fine calibration). In the rest state, there is no pressure on the plastic fins, as a result of which the drives should produce approximately the same resistance over time.

The actuators are designed for normal PETG with 100% infill. If ABS is used, the one number smaller rotor can be used to achieve the same trigger value.

I have printed them in different colors, so I always choose the right part.

Note: I tested the wrench handles with a high-quality 'Stahlwille' torque wrench with calibration certificate, but keep in mind they are self-printed plastic parts: they will never reach the uniformity of professional tools. However, it is usually a question of not exceeding the permitted torque value by several Nm, since we simply have too little feeling in our hands. So often no absolute precision is needed.
A higher value of up to 4Nm (or even 5Nm) would also be conceivable, but then the drive piece would have to be glued in, as otherwise the hexagon in the plastic material would end up with time. We will see...

Enjoy!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

100% (Rotor), 75-100% Case & Cap

Notes:

Print in original orientation for best results. I printed all parts in 0.3mm layer height, but of course lower layers will work as well.

Fill the engravings with color if you like. I've filled mine with Crayola pencils, not perfect, but good enough.

More than about 3Nm is not possible without the bit holder is glued into the rotor, otherwise it would slip. I used 2 component epoxy because PETG does not work well with all adhesives. A ¼" magnet bit holder costs about $4, the easy holder with a square less than $2. I bought mine at Conrad and the brand is Wolfcraft.

Fusion360. The thread in the case is an M45 thread with 2mm pitch, but expanded to 46mm. Thread in the cap is cutted by an scale to 98% of the thread in the case.

PS: the last picture shows the countless attempts that were necessary to come to the result... :)

comments.text:
It's really hard to have a calculation formula, I was playing with the thickness of the fins and their lengths. But slicer and nozzle diameter plays an important role. Just print the 0.5Nm and the 1.0Nm rotor in different materials and if you want, you can play with the extrusion rate. But - as cmh - mentioned, this is a plastic printed part, it's never 100% exact.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I decided to print myself a unique Halloween costume this year after being inspired by pictures of deep sea angler fish. I wanted to make something quirky yet still a little bit terrifying in a good way.

What I ended up with was an angler fish helmet painted in fluro UV paints with very scary teeth.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

The shell was printed with a wall and top/bottom layer thickness of 0.8mm and a 0% fill density. I wanted the parts to be hollow so as to accommodate the rapid expanding foam that I later injected into the hollow shell.

Supports were used whenever there was a large overhang, but if you are creative when you are sectioning up the model you can greatly reduce the need.

The teeth were printed with a 0.8mm thickness and 15% infill. They were printed vertically with both supports and a raft. I found that printing them one at a time achieved the best results, but they could also be printed in a row, positioned in such a way as to reduce build platform travel. If there is too much build platform movement the quality does suffer.

The teeth are also named in order of their position and each file will need to be printed twice except for the top middle tooth.

Assembling the pieces was much more straight forward than anticipated, I simply aligned the pieces, then carefully melted them together using a medium sized soldering iron, when required I'd use excess filament to fill any burn holes or depressions.

In the few instances where things didn't quite align correctly I used a hairdryer to gently heat the pieces till i could manipulate them into the correct shape.

Once the helmet was assembled I drilled a series of holes through the inside of the shell, I then carefully injected rapidly expanding foam into the hollow sections of the printed shells, this made the helmet instantly very durable while still remaining super light.

I then primed the body if the fish in white acrylic paint, before giving it a very fluro paint job. Once I was happy with the paint job I attached the teeth using hot glue, then added the angler rod and light ball. For the rod I simply used some old ptfe tube, but you could use anything.

The colour-changing LED light and battery were cannibalized from a cheap $2 kmart Christmas decoration and connected with some thin enamel copper wire.

The design was roughed up out of primitives in 123D design, then shaped and refined in meshmixer.

The body of the fish was printed out in multiple sections, so depending on the size of your print bed you will need to slice the model up into sections. I found that the simplest way was to slice it vertically down the center line, then carve it up into manageable pieces from there. Splitting it down the center line simply means that you can mirror your STL files when making the second half.

You will want to measure your head, then choose the appropriate scale for you, I have a rather large head so ended up printing it at x17 scale. An easy way to test the fit is to slice the fish cross-ways at the widest part and print a small cross-section to see how it fits.
You will want to scale the teeth by this same factor, however I would suggest making them a fraction smaller to make it more easy to fit them into their sockets.

The cone for holding the angler light rod and the ball for the light are at a x17 scale, so this will have to be adjusted if you change your scale, but this can easily be done in your slicer.

Just by the print of a cover, you're phone will be flying in no time! Here are just a few examples of this being useful. If your friend was grounded and lost their phone, you could FaceTime your phone then fly it to your friend's house and talk to them like that. You could really freak some people out by making your drone talk to them. Plus if you record with your phone, you could get two different cameras on one drone!

comments.text: If you were to fly your phone to your friend's house why would facetime be useful? You would need two phones for that. Also, this only fits one or two phones. Finally, I don't see how this could be used as a camera, because all it would see would either be the sky or the top of the drone. It actually might obstruct the drone's camera, as the Teal Sport camera is top-mounted and this could block it.

description.text: Model of the lunar crater Tycho derived from LOLA data - one of the younger craters with ejecta plumes that reach across much of the visible side.  Part of the ongoing NASA/RISG project to bring space science education to the blind.

As per my other space based prints, used Rhino3D, used the heightfield heightfield command to convert an grayscale converted image from laser altimetry data (http://www.nasa.gov/images/content/565693main_lroc_wac_dtm_tycho.jpg), converted the heightfield to a mesh and applied it to a box structure to give it some height. Printed on a Replicator. Some warpage in my print (there is still a weird issue with slab like prints on the platform not sticking well).

comments.text:
This is an awesome rendition! I love seeing craters from different celestial bodies. However, I think your mesh model is causing some of your troubles.
Note that on the bottom there are 3 'mountains' that stick out - the tallest is about 1.45mm tall. You can see it in the Thingiview (image 3) of your posted pics. Also, it looks like there's a facet or two that interfere on one of the sides (the staticy triangle to the upper left in image 3). Running this through the repair module in MeshLab might help with those.

author: schrotti

description.text:
Cone filler, for king size & 98 special, based on raw loader.
included scraping card and stick poker.

  1. slide your cone over the tip of the funnel
  2. hold your cone to the loader between your thumb and forefinger (like a gentle pinch on the sides)
  3. use the included card to move material into the funnel
  4. using the narrow end of the included poker, push your material down the chute and into the cone. push it. push it real good.
  5. as you fill the cone, you may want to begin using the wide end of the poker. this way you can pack your cone progressively tighter.
  6. when your cone is full, act like you are giving it a final poke, but this time loosen your grip on the cone and push your cone right off the funnel. it will help prevent spillage.. and you'll look cool as hell doing it.
  7. finally you may finish packing with the poker, if you wish.

A fancy unicorn horn for a costume. Made from three parts so you can print it at home.

Printer:

Heavily modded Craftbot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm or less

Infill:

10%

Notes:

You should be able to print this on a medium-sized 3D printer (25x20x20 cm volume).
This model is modelled for 21 cm long head (the longest distance from back of the head to the forehead). If your head is smaller, scale all three pieces by the same factor to get the proper size for your head. (E.g. if your head is 19 cm long, use 19/21 = 90,5% scaling factor for all three pieces.)
Orient both horn parts almost vertically, until the bottom flat is horizontal. Use a small amount of support (10% or less) for the headpiece an a larger amount (15-20% + interface ) for the horns to prevent them from moving too much while printing. Use cooling when printing horn parts.

• Clean up prints and glue the two horn parts to the headpiece.
  • Add a rubber band to the holes in the back.
  • Put the whole thing on the head so the horn looks upwards from your forehead and the back part with the rubber band is under the little bump on the back of your head - this makes it stable.
  • Try not to poke somebody's eye out. You might put a foam ball on the point when in situations involving a lot of people. You can take it off for good looks in photos and the replace it for dancing etc.

title: Turn Cordinator for Flight Simulator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Stick and Ball Gauge for use in panel of GA Flight Simulators.
It's need 2 servos of 9gr. like SG90, and will be conected to the PC with the flight simulator via OpenCockpits Servo Board, a Arduino or similar system.

Please, be aware that depend of the branch of servos, you may need to modifi fondo4.stl or put some separator on the servos screws.

ring.stl is a optional piece in case you want to put a glass or plastic and the thick of panel is not enought.

You need to print acople_servo.stl twice, but only need to print one of avion1.stl or avion2.stl

You need several 4 M3 screws and nuts for fix the pieces and the instrument to the panel.

Print, glue and cut the background image over fondo2.stl and fondo3.stl, as show in the picture.

use white PLA for fondo4, or glue a white piece of paper for the ball background.

It's a modification of my other gauges, bezel and other piezes can be shared, so check my other gauges for change the style of the gauge.

title: Lothlorien Brooch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Meant to resemble the elven brooches from the LotR movies, given to the fellowship when leaving Lothlorien. Depending on scale and added hardware, it could be used for many things. I glues a magnetic sheet to the back of one to make a magnet. The original intent was as a handle for a window pull in the treehouse project. The lastest model was for corrections and use in my son's Legolas costume.
I'm including a file of the entire pbject as well as the two parts separated for printing with multiple filaments. I've printed with and without supports and it came out fine. Your printer settings might make the difference.
As for infill, it depends on how hefty you want it. I did 100% to make a solid piece and it was nice, but I did 50% on the version for my son's costume and it was perfectly fine. I'm sure lower would be fine as well.
I printed in a single filament and hand painted afterward.
The "green" part is pretty much just flat, I might edit it to give it more character, but when painted and glossy clear coated, it has character enough.
Scale as needed. I designed in blender, but forgot to set the world scale. In my slicer I scaled it up and it works perfectly. Smaller is highly likely to not show the thinner veins running on the leaf. I did a print as 2.5 inches and they show well. My final costume print was 3 inches.

Qidi Tech 1

title: Fly lure rattler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This was a simple tubular case I designed when I needed to add some rattle effect to a streamer type fly I created to catch peacock bass where I live. Seems to work well, helps to draw the peacock bass out of hiding to take a closer look and attack the lure. Please see the following setup I used when printing and putting together this 3D print case below.

  1. Scale the case part up 135%
  2. Scale the cap up 128%
  3. You'll need to ensure the Z offset for your printer is close enough that you won't need to use any sort of additional adhesion to the build plate. It may not print well using raft type adhesion.
  4. Add 4 pieces of 2.8mm diameter split shots or ball bearings of similar size and cap it. Apply a little sealant to the gaps of the cap to ensure its water tight. I've used super glue and it seems to work well for me.
  5. Last but not least, add this when tying your next streamer lure and enjoy.

title: 3D Printed Linear Rail
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Since starting to build a Dollo3D for myself, I've been interested in testing how far one can get with 3D printed parts. One of the problem areas with Dollo has been the Z-axis and for now I've resorted to using metallic lead screws. However, I didn't want to buy linear rails, I wanted to print them. Also I wanted the rail setup to be extensible, even though the lead screw isn't (yet). So came up with this setup where the slide has kind of spring mechanism so tolerances don't need to be 100%. Also it slides quite easily, making it a good option for Z-axis rail as it usually doesn't move that fast.

Source available in here: https://github.com/spegelius/Dollo/blob/master/NEW_long_ties/rail.scad

I've been running 4 ~50cm beams for something like 6 months now and the setup is still going on strong. Even with not so straight lead screws, the prints are coming great regards Z-axis. Lubricant strongly advised, I use PTFE based spray.

There are of course things to improve, like the joint between the rail parts and maybe making the parts smaller in diameter. Work in progress.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

02-0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

2 perimeters and not much infill needed in my experience. YMMV of course. Printed with PLA as I like to have the rails stiff.

Connecting multiple rails together is accomplished with the inner block. I also used soldering iron to melt the ends together while having them held in straight line. And sanded the junctions afterwards.

Lubricant strongly advised, I use PTFE based spray. Also some kind of silicone grease seems to work even better.

If the inner block doesn't fit or is too loose, use your slicer sw to scale it in X and Z dimensions.

I saw a few things from Dollo, and I found it has almost zero practical build tutorials. I just found demonstration videos, no video or other detailed stuff how to build it. Search for Dollo in Thingiverse, I just found your printed linear rails... I think it is amazing. The printer in photos is a Dollo? Could you share more information about your Dollo Printer and how to mount your linear rails in it? I hope I'm not asking too much... for me just the descriptions in Dollo github are not enough (I'm newbie, like I said). title: Towelhanger for glue on the wall

description.text:
Tried some of the designs found on www.thingiverse.com but as most of them was not good designs and the one I liked has a error in the design so it prints a spacing in the layer for the hock, making the hock break of but the foot stay on the wall. So I got tired looking for finish made design and made my own.

This can hold 3 towels at same time, one on each nob and one in the crack of the 2 nobs.

Make sure u glue it good to the wall and do a stress test on it before glue it.

I used 45% infill because my towels are large.

Depending on how you turn the model, you might not need support.

The original Solid Edge PAR file follows, as well the STL file.

Update! Both the PAR and the STL size is to small so a scale of 200 present will do good. However, scaling will increase the crack of the 2 nobs so you might need to edit the PAR file and I recommend a spacing of only 1mm, then save it as STL and then scale it by 200%, this will make the crack distance perfect. Also I found that having it standing while printing makes best result.

title: Amiibo Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
IMPORTANT NOTE: Yes, there's a chance that you may not be able to print this. But I'm working on a modular version which anyone can print, and I should have it up in a new Thing soon! The best way to be alerted to the posting of this new modular Amiibo stand design/Thing is to follow me. So go ahead and do that now, if that helps!

This is unprintable on my FlashForge Creator Pro. I should have done the math, or a preliminary sketch, first. But yeah...way too big. The maximum print size on the FFCP 2016 edition is 228mm x 148mm x 150mm (XYZ), and the size of this is hilariously much larger.

SO, I offer this to you for two reasons:

1) If you have a maximum printable area that is 380mm x 240mm x 160mm (XYZ) then please, absolutely print this, share a Make, and tell me how awesome it works for organizing your Amiibo!

2) I want people to help me design a better version that is either small enough to fit on the bed, OR, think of a way to make it modular, so that everyone can print the parts, and snap/slide/glue them together to make something this size.

So, please leave me a comment or, if you have a large enough machine, a Make, and let's talk about ways to make an Amiibo display stand more practical for folks with reasonable-sized print beds!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

You will not print this on a FlashForge Creator Pro. :)

If you print this on something with a larger bed size, please let me know which one! Is it an affordable unit? Should I be investing in my next sub-$1,000 3D printer for items as large as this? Thanks!

Crying

So many tears when I pulled this model up into Simplify3D. It was hilarious! It even gave me a warning that it was too big for the bed. I knew it wasn't an inches-to-mm conversion issue because it was my own model, and, well, I save STL files properly. I always use mm.

So, yes, "post-printing" was actually NO printing. I suspect, with everything being completely vertical and horizontal, this would print perfectly. You'd have your standard layer lines, and I'm sure if your bed is wiggling, you'd have non-flush sizes. But that's what happens when you design something that's perfectly flush, square, level. It will show any flaws in the design process.

I suspect you could print this, and then just prime and paint it. Or not. The Amiibo are the centerpieces, and should take center stage. Print this in a color that is bland, so it won't stand out. Maybe beige? Black? White even?

Good artists copy; great artists steal.

I took this idea from the following guide:

https://imgur.com/gallery/P68cT

I tweaked things a little, to make more room for three larger Amiibo on the top, and I had to convert from inches to mm, and then make things still visually appealing design-wise. Ratios are important!

I used Fusion 360 to design this from scratch, using the guide above as a general idea. The next version will be better, trust me!

title: Another Anet Nozzle Cleaning Brush Mount

description.text:
I really liked Sloppsta's idea of the nozzle cleaning brush in https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2355355.

But... I have a hotbed strain relief mount (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2474429) bolted to the rear of the two bearing block mounts on the bed holder so I couldn't use that position.

And I had already designed and printed some "corners" for my bed. These are used to hold the spring, and a captive nut. I have drilled out the thread on the bed and use a thumb wheel to adjust the bed height. Three of these corner pieces have screws to hold a 3mm glass sheet in place and the final one is in what I call the "home corner"; where the nozzle goes back to. This corner bracket is lower (so is not above the glass at all) and just holds the glass in place.

So I thought it would be fun to take the idea above and make it part of this home-corner piece. A benefit I saw of mounting it as part of the corner piece is that the height of the brush stays exactly the same when the bed is re-levelled.

I have included the OpenSCAD design file so you should be able to adapt the design to suit any reasonably sized brush head as an alternative.

Depending on your needs you probably should use a more heat-resistant filament than PLA. I printed my corners and the brush holder using PETG and seems to be fine with the bed at 80'C.

I also included a picture of the brushes I bought from eBay for a couple of pounds so you get an idea of the type I used. I simply hacksawed off the plastic handle.

I have also included a short gcode file showing how to move the nozzle back and forth across the brush head to clean it. Obviously you will need to check and adjust this to suit your own set up.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You should rotate the "key" STL so it sits flat on the surface of the slicer. This slots in at the end to stop the brush from moving about.

description.text:
Buddy Snake is a bendable snake skeleton that can be made to any desirable length and worn wherever made to fit.

For my first buddy snake seen in the pictures I made it long enough to be worn as a bracelet. Adding several more rib cages (Bone.STL) it could be long enough to be worn as a necklace or even along one's waist.

To make a Buddy Snake you'll need the following:

  • Non insulated 14 Gauge wire (smaller gauge might work with insulation, that's 16+ Gauge)
  • Needle Nose Pliers (for cutting and bending the wire)
  • 3D printer with filament (but you knew that)
  • 32 Bone.STL (for bracelet) 50-60 Bone.STL (for necklace) 60+ Bone.STL (for something bigger)
  • 1 Head.STL
  • 1 Tail.STL
  • Anything additional you'd like to add such as paint or googly eyes

For my Buddy Snake seen in the pictures I printed 32 rib cages (Bone.STL) 1 Head.STL and 1 Tail.STL. This made Buddy Snake about 12 inches in length (305mm). By adding more rib cages (Bone.STL) Buddy Snake could be worn as a necklace or even along one's waist.

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I recommend using a 100% infill as the parts are small. The 3D files I've uploaded have the parts in what is likely there best orientation. If you are using a heavier gauge wire you'll need to scale the model up.

Assembly

After printing the desired number of rib cages (Bone.STL) 1 Head.STL and 1 Tail.STL break off all supports, there'll be one inside the head and tail cavity as well. Cut wire that'll be longer than your snake and fish the tail on first then crimp the wire to prevent the tail from sliding off the wire (see picture). After adding all the rib cages (see assembly sketch for orientation) slide the head on and there is enough of a cavity in the head to bend and crimp the wire inside it (see picture).

title: IoT air freshener

description.text:
Instructables Wireless Contest 2017 First Prize Winner!!! :D

Full instructions at Instructables website:
https://www.instructables.com/id/IoT-Air-Freshner-with-NodeMCU-Arduino-IFTTT-and-Ad/

There are lot of Air Fresheners in the market: from the old manual sprays, to timer triggered ones. The later ones, although automatic, are quite dumb: they will keep spraying even if you're not even close to feel the smell, wasting those not so inexpensive fragrance refills!

Wouldn't it be nice if your air freshener was capable of communicating with other gadgets and trigger only when you really needed it?

In this project I designed an IoT Air Freshener, using some 3D printing, a NodeMCU, IFTTT and Adafruit.IO. The gadget might be programmed to be triggered when you are home, at a given time, when you push a button, or even to notify if you've got mail!

Did you know you can buy a Anet A8 for only $129.99?

title: Geek Chic - Emissary / Envoy - Under Table Rail Accessories
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Geek Chic made great Tabletop (board game, RPG, miniatures) gaming tables. They also had a great rail to attach accessories (desks, dice towers, cup holders) to the side of the table to enhance your gaming experience. Many people shelled out a small fortune for these tables. Unfortunately, they went under (no longer in business).

I happily bought rail accessories from them in the past. Now I have no way to buy them, and their rail system was unique to the table, so there are no 3rd party vendors.

I made the files, tested, and printed. I used PLA and Wood PLA. They came out nice. You can stain Wood PLA.

This one fits the underside table on the Emissary, Scout or Envoy.
See my other thing for the ones that fit the other rail system.

If you prefer me to print them out for you, check out my Etsy storefront.

You will need:
2 screws (10-24 1.5" can work).
2 nuts to match the screws.

You can glue them in between.

You will also need two pegs. I have found the 3/16" Cribbage Pegs (found at Amazon) to work well.

title: Linear toggle clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This design is based on a toggle clamp and the difference is that the last part of the stroke is linear. As an example, this feature is useful for applications in which a probe must come in contact with a PCBA to test or program it. This is where I got the idea from. This design can be used like a normal toggle clamp because a fair amount of force can be applied at he end of the stroke and the clamp will hold just fine. I tried it with the kitchen scale and 3kg was not a problem but this was the maximum value of the scale.

This design consist of 16 parts (2× part 12) as can be seen in the PDF drawing. The linear stroke is as long as the slot in part 6 and 11 which is 10mm.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-100

Notes:

The thread of part 4, 5, 9 and 15 is a modified M8 trapezoidal thread with a pitch of 2.5mm. Regular M8 thread is to small to print. I recommend printing part 5 individually at a slightly lower temperature like 190°C and a layer height of 0.2mm and with a 8mm brim. You want to put as little heat as possible in this part. The infill of the axes, (part 1, 7 and 10) and the threaded parts (4, 5 and 15) is 100%. In other words, completely solid. This is not important for the other pieces.

The two 6mm holes of part 6 and 11 must be drilled afterwards to 6mm and the same goes for the 5mm hole of part 13 and 14. The parts 1, 7 and 10 are then pressed into these holes. I just did this with a hammer and a 6mm socket wrench. Don’t forget to place part 2 before mounting the axes. The rest speaks for itself.

End result of the linear toggle clamp

description.text:
The revised and updated GoPro session mount for the R5(L)X.

This is also primarily designed around a top mounted battery. It includes a 25, 30, 40 and 50 degree mount. Additionally I have added a 25 degree mount with a GPS holder.

It is now about 10g lighter, handles vibrations much better, and fully supports super view. I have been running this design for quite a while now and have yet to break it.

Running this mount with a top mounted battery has given a much better feel on the quad, especially in Betaflight.

Notes:

I set the resolution at 1.8 and the infill at 10 to cut down on the print time. It took about 5 hours per half to print this car.

After Printing

The support was slightly difficult to remove from the inside of the body. The gap distance may need to be adjusted. Also the mirrors immediately broke off after printing. I just used some super glue to re-attach them. I used super glue to assemble the two halves of the car as well. Aside form the assembly I just had to cut off some loose strings and the build support. I used a knife to scrap the support attach points in the wheel wells to clear the wheels.

Design

I created two TInkerCAD files and removed half of the car in each.

title: Frame Motor for Kossel / Deltaprinter 20x20
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is sort of a remix from the Kossel "frame_motor_2020sw".
Which means i created the thing completely new in fusion360.

I could not found the source because there are so many of these parts on thingiverse.

Changes i made:

  • changed the distance for the motor, to ad a vibration damper which i found here
    https://de.aliexpress.com/item/Hot-sale-5-pcs-lot-Nema-17-stepper-motor-Vibration-Damper-shock-absorber-for-42-step/32764435765.html
  • made the cutout for t-nuts bigger
  • made holes through the whole part for tighten the screws for the motor
  • made a small cutout on the underside for cables (endstops)
  • smaller radius next to the screws, which holds the motor for adding washers
  • just 3 instead of 4 from this long sections parallel to the extrusion

Version 1: Tested. A little bit hard to insert the extrusion, and not to much space for cables on the underside.

Version 2: Tested. Bigger cutout on the underside (radius 5mm instead of 2.5mm), smaller radius in the corners, where the extrusion goes through (0.5mm instead of 1mm)

Version 3: Tested. Small update. Rounded the corner/area where the cable bends from the underside to the extrusion. Had some troubles to move the cable, when the extrusion was in place. And changed the logo slightly :-)

Any feedback is welcome

description.text:
This is a pony warren Truss bridge (it's a pony because the sides are not connected to one another at the top). Warren because of the arrangement of the vertical members.   I like this type of Truss bridge because I don't have to worry about the vertical clearance.  
.stl files are for O scale, HO-scale and N/Z scale. Scale them for your needs.

This is a model of a pony Warren Truss bridge. I like it because there aren't any cross members so I don't have to worry about vertical clearance. I took some liberties in the design to make printing easier. The inside of the i-beams are curved to make printing easier. Three versions are provided: one for O or S, one for HO, and one for N or Z. The models were scaled in OpenSCAD so that the i-beams were more appropriate for the scale. You can further scale these models to meet your needs. The dimensions of the O design are
  • track width = 60 mm
  • overall bridge width = 90 mm
  • length = 200 mm
  • overall height = 49.3 mm
    • The dimensions of the HO design are
  • track width = 36 mm
  • overall bridge width = 54 mm
  • length = 150 mm
  • overall height = 31.8 mm
    • The dimensions of the N design (also for Z) are
  • track width = 21 mm
  • overall bridge width = 31.5 mm
  • length = 100 mm
  • overall height = 21.6 mm
    • Parts list: None. Assembly instructions: None. Printing Instructions: The bridge tends to warp lengthwise. Adhesion to the build plate is very important. The i-beams were designed for printing. There really shouldn't be much cleanup of the bridges except for the upper i-beams on the O scale. If you are using blue tape, small holes in it won't affect the printing because it will be on the bottom of the bridge. The design is based loosely on Google images of various bridges around the world. Features and dimensions of real bridges were altered for the simplicity of the design and to make the bridge printable. Model train info (approximate values and may depend on manufacturer (1" equals 25.4 mm) O27 scale 1:48, track ~50.0-mm W x 10.3-mm H, typical car ~54.8-mm W x 79.3-mm H, car+track ~ 89.6 mm H, 1-ft = 6.4 mm S scale 1:64, track ~47.0-mm W x 13.6-mm H, typical box car 51.2-mm W x 67.8-mm H, car+track ~ 81.4-mm H, 1 ft=4.8 mm HO 1:87, track ~28.5-mm W x 4.6-mm H, typical box car 36.0-mm W x 55.8-mm H, car+track ~60.4-mm H, 1 ft=3.6 mm N 1:160, track ~16.0-mm W x 3.8-mm H, typical box car 20.3-mm W x 31.5-mm H, car+track ~ 35.3-mm H, 1 ft=1.9 mm Z 1:220, track ~16.0-mm W x 4.7-mm H, typical box car 15.6-mm W x 21.9-mm H, car+track ~ 26.6-mm H, 1 ft=1.4 mm (Lionel O track is 4.4-mm higher than O27 track).
    I have not listed G scale because it's too big for my designed parts. Some best practices for printing:
  • optimize print parameters for your printer, filament, etc (only you can determine the best parameters)
  • use good filament
  • level your build plate prior to printing complex parts. it's worth the few minutes it takes. always level after removing tape, or if pulling hard to remove a part.
  • make sure the build plate is clean.
  • if using blue tape, stretch it tight when applying it to the build plate.
  • pre-feed the filament 30 to 60-s before printing (i.e., run load for 30-60s)
  • do not print several complicated parts in one build (do complex parts by themselves)
  • I find that printing faster is better (probably so the filament can't ball up in one spot)
  • when the filament spool gets low, the filament can be tightly wound on the spool and the filament may not feed properly... take special care...
  • when a new spool is used, it is easy for the filament to jump outside the spool and then it will bind up later around the spool holder ruining your build
  • make sure it is easy for the filament to enter the filament feed tube. others have designed spools, mounts, etc. for that purpose. i use a small rope that forces the filament away from the spool before entering the filament feed tube.
  • if you hear clicking when printing, that may be a result of the filament wrapped around the spool and not feeding
  • make sure that there aren't any obstructions on the spool, such as some filament used to hold it in place during shipping
  • for the replicaor2, look at the blob a filament in the left front part of the build plate and then the trail of filament to the biuild location. there should be a glob, and the line of filament should be continuous and smooth
  • one way to remove parts when using blue tape is to use a very thin spatula bought in craft-art stores (advice from youtube). get one with a wide, blunt front end (not long and thin). mine is 11 mils thick (0.011") and 20-mm wide at the front. a painting spatula/scraper in hardware stores won't work and may damage the build plate. (I use blue tape so I don't have any best practices for bare plates, heated plates or for other tapes like mylar)
  • perform regular maintenance (grease, etc).
  • when I continued to have problems printing even after performing maintenance, following troublshooting instructions, changing filaments, cleaning gears, cleaning everything, optimizing print parameters, changing temperatures, etc., I bought a new extruder assembly from Makerbot and it solved all of my problems.

title: Cracking like Nuts (cnc)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We have a huge walnut tree in our garden. Cracking all those nuts open is a pretty hard job. I got a nice nutcracker which I actually used as template for an own version. The only downside is, that it takes a good amount of force to crack the nuts. The 'Cracking like Nuts' uses another approach: the excentric handle gives a nice amount of leverage. As the handle pushes the nuts to the end it is impossible to lose grip.

To build it, I took some 20 mm walnut, which is kind of recursive :) and milled the parts on my desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft. Again I did without double sided machining. The base parts are glued an a machine-screw (M5) works as the bolt. No counternut it needed if the hole in the second half of the base is a little smaller.

I am not sure if a print from plastics could take the force, but if someone wants to try I'd be glad to get feedback.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

The original RigidBot R1 3D printer does not have the glass.
Due to the construction of the plate and the presence of some bolts, is is hard to mount a glass, since it needs to be cut at measure and the holders may crash against the motor. Here is a very simple and ingenuous glass holder. This THING will allow you to have an easy way to install and remove the glass, so that you can remove it and put on a table "before" applying brutal force on the objects to detach them, without the fear to damage your RigidBot.
This object is designed for a standard borosilicate glass standard size of 250x250 mm.
If you are so lucky to have a custom cut glass of 250x270 mm, then you don't need the printed bricks, and you need to mount just the aluminium bars over the glass with the clips.

Thanks to this THING, you ma use a glass with blue tape for cold print, and another glass only & hair spray for HOT bed ABS print.

The plastic blocks under the bars, are calibrated for a 3mm glass. If you have a different glass height you will need to adjust the STL objects to match your glass height.

REQUIRED MATERIALS:

  • ALL the printed .STL objects
  • Borosilicate glass 250x250mm
  • 4 office clips 25 x 10 mm
  • 54 cm of Aluminium profile in L shape (20x10x2) commonly available, to be cut in 2 pieces of 270 mm
  • 4 duct pieces of 30 mm.
  • 4 pieces of scotch double side of 30 mm.

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS:
Read the instruction PDF.

Here is another Seattle Seahawks design with a very practical use for all fans of this US football team. It's two colors so you will need to first start with white and then pause the print and change it to blue at the correct layer. The clear coat I used to protect the top is Envirotex Lite, two-part, pour on, high gloss resin. When you mix it you will invariably get bubbles in the resin. The way to remove them is to run a small, hand-held butane torch quickly over the bubbles before the resin sets. They will pop as the flame passes over them.

You can find out more about this resin from Environmental Technology, Inc. https://www.eti-usa.com/

Enjoy!

I made these standoffs to mount the PI and its case to the back of my monitor. They're made to fit the cases floating around that have the standard VESA mounts. They press fit in the holes, sort of, depending on the accuracy of your printer, and are meant to have double-sided 3M sticky tape applied to the foot end for attaching to the monitor. An alternative to a press fit is to make the pin slightly undersized so the case will just slide on/off easily and use small o-rings on them to keep the case from slipping off. I printed them out of ABS with a solid infill, 2 mm layer height.

description.text:
Remixed the great model by Bjornnijen; scaled to what I feel is the right size for a fridge magnet and added two holes for magnets to be put in. Used standard 8mmx3mm neodymium magnets, like these:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B073RVQHKT/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

When preparing to print make sure to add a pause to the gcode before the holes get closed off so you can add the magnets (I put a dot of super glue on them so they stick to the print and don't get pulled out by the hotend). The magnet pause should be around 3.4mm layer height and the color change pause should be around 4.4mm.

In case anyone is curious about my layer height pause gcode, I just insert these commands at the layer I want to pause:

G1 X245 Y205 Z180 ; move head all the way to top right back
M300 S300 P1000 ; play beep sound to signal attention
M0 Click To Restart ; pause and wait for the user

Keep in mind those work for my printer, you may want to use different coordinates for the first command based on your print volume.

Filaments I used:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00YSPCN76/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00J0GPC80/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

For use with diversity receivers like FrSky XM+ and others.

description.text:
Update 2017-12-31: I've uploaded a stronger arm with a slightly larger diameter post and reinforcing rib: arm_ball_v2.stl

==========

This is a remix/mix of parts from two Raspberry Pi Zero +Camera mounts:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2285502
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2433291

I'm using it with an AnyCubic i3 Mega, but there is nothing specific for that printer because it attaches with a 3M CommandStrip,

Changes:

  1. I added a socket mount from 79DieselRabbit to RaspberryPI_MOUNTV2 by dktosoch.
  2. I found that the original socket bracket was too flexible when the ball was in place so I made it thicker to put more of the pressure on the socket itself.
  3. I scaled the 5cm ball arm up by 5% to increase friction as per a discussion thread on the original mount.

I found that even with the increased friction on the ball and socket, that it would not stay in place once I put the Pi in the mount. Since I don't need the mount to be articulated, I added a couple drops of super glue to each ball/socket once I had it positioned where I wanted for OctoPi.

There may be a better ball and socket design out there, but for now I'm staying with the parts from the two sources.

title: Two Part Bugatti Veyron Pinewood Derby

description.text: This was a difficult model to print. The resolution of my printer or the Cura slicer that I used would not let me print the windows well. There were some holes in the body as well. I think it would have printed better as a solid. The sectioned models were not working for me so I put it in TinkerCAD to cut the car in half. I had to remove a random structure that was on the inside of the car where the block should go. I think it was an error in the file. I added structure behind the side windows in hopes of supporting them. While I was printing the support structure for the rear part failed. Luckily I was near by and I was able to stand it back up while I paused the print. It lined up fairly well but I had to use some JB Weld to fill in a gap after printing. Ultimately though it was still a cool print.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

1.8

Infill:

10

Notes:

I printed 1.8 resolution and 10 infill to save printing time. It took about 6 hours per half.

After Printing

It was really difficult to remove the build support. I probably should have adjusted the gap between the part and the support.

I added some JB Weld to the rear to fill a gap that occurred when the rear portion of the rear half of the car fell off the build plate because of weak support. I was able to stand it back up, align it, and continue printing though.

Build Support Remains Added JB Weld to fill gap caused by rear section falling off during the print.

Design

I cut the car in half using TinkerCAD. I also had to remove a structure on the inside of the car where the block goes. It looked like some sort of glitch from downloading.

File structure glitch.

author: Tunxis3DPrinting

description.text: This is a model of a chain I made for part of my Halloween Costume. The Chain is in the perfect orientation to have limited supports and should be quite simple to remove. Once the supports are taken off the chain will go from stiff to free moving. I have scaled it down to the size of a Lego chain and had success, just be more careful when removing the supports. You may notice a link or two that is fused, shouldn't be more than a few, this is due to the corners where the chain changes direction on the print bed. Be sure to have a clean print bed for better adhesion as there is not much surface area on the print.

title: Hex Wrench for Tire Valve Caps

description.text:
Here are two wrenches for Tire Valve Caps. One is sized to fit a hex cap that is 9.5 mm across the flats. The other is for a cap that is 12 mm across the flats.

Chances are good you will need a size that isn't here, but you can scale one of them to meet your needs. If you adjust the size, start with the one that is closest to your cap dimensions. Scaling it down will also reduce the wall thickness and weaken the wrench.

update 11/11/17 replaced larger wrench with one with modified handle and corrected spelling.

Why bother with something like this?
In places where a schrader valve is used (tires, Air conditioning, etc. The cap IS the primary seal, not the schrader valve. The valve just prevents the gas from rushing out while the cap is put in place and provides an inexpensive means of injecting gas into the item. Schrader valves can be notoriously leaky over their life.
If this makes sense to you, you may want to check the caps and seals on your home and auto AC compressors; they are very inexpensive and service techs don't have an incentive to check them (you will be back sooner if the gas needs to be added). AC pressures easily run 10X that of an auto tire, and the gas is more expensive! Keeping tires properly inflated increases their life and your gas mileage.

A small wrench allows you to apply enough torque to ensure that the cap is seated well. Depending upon the sealing material, you might be able to apply enough torque with your bare hands. If your metal caps don't have a sealing ring, their only function will be to keep dust from entering the valve stem. Adding an O-Ring inside the cap provides a good seal.

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa I3 Dual w/ mods

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used a 0.4 mm nozzle & 0.3mm layer height.

Infill:

I used 20%

Notes:

Print with the hex cavity down. One of the wrenches has to be rotated.

Use at least two perimeters so it is strong enough. I used PLA, which has proved plenty strong in the time I have used the smaller one.

title: Pogoplug faceplate for desk conversion and weight reduction

description.text: The lovable, hackable Pogoplug! Whatever tasks I'd assign to these cheap little linux boxes, I'd always find the form factor a little lacking. With this front plate, you can drastically reduce the weight of the unit, make it stackable, and give it a more professional appearance.

Simply disassemble your Pogoplug to remove it from the original "Pogo stick" mount, and then snap this faceplate on. This faceplate works with or without the (heavy) extra plastic shell you remove before disassembling the unit. I prefer to use it without the shell.  
Disassembly - grip the clear plastic shell and use your thumbs on the back of the unit while pulling on the plastic. Use a flat head screw driver to pry up the main case and unclip it from its other half. Unscrew the board if you have difficulty removing the original mount, and then snap the main case back together.

Airbrush Stand for Badger Velocity airbrush, with a cap holder.

description.text:
This is a contraption I designed to allow me to very quickly scan thousands of my parents 35mm slides. The slide drops in the small slot, put your phone in the back slot and have your phone display a white screen at full brightness (there are several free apps that can do this). Then use your dslr with an appropriate macro lens to copy the slide. I use a panasonic GH5 and a sigma 105mm macro lens. I set the camera to aperture priority mode at f8. I also enable the HDR mode in the menu to maximize the dynamic range. I white balanced manually on the lighted surface of the phone. Some film stocks looked better by manipulating the white balance a bit, but this provides a good starting point.
Personally, I mounted the contraption to a piece of wood and then mounted a manfrotto plate receiver at the other end. The manfrotto system allows about 3-4 inches of sliding front to back, so it's easier to get the slide to fill the frame at the given focus distance. The height can be adjusted by placing washers between the slide holder and the wood. Mine is about 1/4" up. And lastly, I put black gaff tape on the inside of a shoe box and covered most everything with the box to eliminate any stray light. I'm very pleased with the results and I can scan about 8-10 slides a minute with this method. The tinkercad link is below, this could easily be modified to accept different formats of film slides or negatives. I think the phone slot is big enough to accommodate most phones, but feel free to remix it to your needs.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jHZOsaaTYwF

subject to change

Notes:

You can print these with full structural integrity at 0 percent infill but with 7-9 shells.

Requirements

You will need two of each file, some paracord, and two 1/4 inch by 1 1/2 inch bolts with their corresponding nuts.

Step 1

Start by beveling the tops and bottoms of the connectors and meeting points of the holes on the top middle and bottom files.

Step 2

Sand the connectors and use a round file in the holes to make assembly easier. Work the parts down until you can insert a connector halfway into a hole by hand.

Step 3

Insert the longer connector into the hole in the bottom file with the help of a hammer, then insert the protruding end into one of the holes in the middle file. Through all of this, be sure to line up the edges of the sections so the finished product appears constant. Insert the shorter connector into the top hole in the middle file and finally insert it into the last hole in the top file.

Step 4

take a piece of paracord or other strong cordage and tie in it a square knot so it makes a loop about an inch larger than the width of your hand. Put the ends into the string holes on the top file and tighten through the 1/4 inch nut and bolt. Repeat on both sides, and you're finished!

Square Knot Tutorial Stringing Tutorial

title: Customizable spiral vase Sierpinski pyramid (subtractive model)

description.text:
This is a variation on the square Sierpinksi pyramid. The difference with the straightforward pyramid is the addition of inverted pyramids to make this 3D printable. As described in ricktu's and aeropic's original Things this one is based on, the 3D model can ideally be printed in ‘spiral vase’ or ‘spiralize outer contour’ modes of slicing programs, which means the whole print can be done in one single continuous line with no retractions. This produces a model of high quality in a surprisingly short time (and it causes your printer to make funky sounds).

One of the problems with ricktu's original model, is that it does not work with Slic3r's spiral mode. However, neither does aeropic's model, for two reasons:

  1. It uses gaps of 0.01mm, while Slic3r fills gaps smaller than 0.1 mm (see issue 520 in the Prusa3D Slic3r GitHub). This breaks the spiral shape.
  2. The parts connecting the pyramids are too small, which causes them to become separate perimeters as well.

I started out fixing these issues, but in the end I rewrote a large part of the code to construct the model in a subtractive way. Instead of stacking small pyramids together like aeropic's code, holes are cut out of one big solid pyramid. This produces a cleaner model, and avoids inaccuracies or slicing errors when cutting right at the division between two pyramids. Of course I also had to litter the code with fudge factors and some geometric tweaks, to avoid non-manifoldness problems which Slic3r is particularly sensitive to.

Another change is that the model will auto-align itself to the print layer height (default: 0.2 mm). This ensures a consistent print from top to bottom, it also means you only need to check whether the bottom level of a model will print correctly, because the higher levels will be printed in exactly the same way. The same goes for the order parameter: if a model of order 2 prints alright, then an order 3 or 4 model with the same parameters will print in exactly the same way.

Making a custom pyramid
You can make your own custom pyramid in Customizer. If Customizer is broken on the Thingiverse website, here are instructions to run it on your own computer.
Customizer is limited to an order 4 pyramid, because higher orders take so much time that the Thingiverse server would most likely timeout, leaving you with no model. If you want to generate an order 5 pyramid, you will need to download the SCAD file and run it through OpenSCAD yourself. On my computer, it took about 90 minutes to generate the order 5 file included with this Thing.
It currently seems impossible to generate an order 6 model, because of inherent limitations in OpenSCAD. You could skim through the OpenSCAD bugs to see if there is an existing bug that covers this, so you can upvote it, or file a new one if you think there isn't any.

There is a ‘Z scale’ option, keep it at 1 to obtain an equilateral pyramid (like ricktu's model) that also fits my display stand, set it to 1.2 to get the same shape as aeropic's model.

Do not scale generated models for printing, unless you know what you're doing. The gap size will also be scaled, and this can mess up spiral mode, or cause an ugly print.

Despite all the changes I made, it still is not guaranteed that Slic3r (and possibly other slicers) will always print the entire model in spiral mode, especially when printing at small sizes. The problem is, it is possible for layers to be sliced at a height where there are tiny zig-zags in the contours that will be omitted, which breaks the spiral. For this reason, there is an advanced option in Customizer to shift the whole model upwards. See the instructions below to check whether you need to do this.

I provide a few pre-generated models at 1.5 mm size optimized for 0.2 mm layer height, these are quite similar in size to ricktu's. I have cleaned up these models in Blender to remove redundant polygons, for a smaller download and smoother previews. Whether you will run into the problem of the spiral being interrupted or not with these models, will depend on your first layer height and your slicer.

Notes:

As the description says, you should be able to print this in ‘Spiral vase’ mode. Other slicers use different names for this: Cura calls it ‘Spiralize outer contour’ (may need to be activated in the preferences), in S3D it is ‘Corkscrew/vase’.

I recommend to print one solid bottom layer for better adhesion, meaning the spiral should only start after this first layer. If spiral mode works correctly, there will not be a single retraction move in the entire print after this first layer.

To avoid that the tip of the pyramid melts together, especially when printing in PLA or PETG, be sure to provide sufficient cooling at the end of the print.

This is optimized for a 0.4 mm nozzle. If you would want to print this with a larger nozzle, you will need to tweak some parameters in the SCAD file (I didn't put them in Customizer to make it less confusing).

description.header: Ensuring a true spiral mode print
description.text:
It is possible that the model will be sliced exactly at Z coordinates where certain details are too small for the slicer program to create one continuous contour, and you will get multiple disconnected contours, as shown here:

It is not a disaster if this happens, because some retract and travel moves will be inserted to print those separate squares. However, this can cause scars on the final print, and it increases print time, so it is better to avoid it. You can usually get rid of the problem by shifting up the whole print a little bit. You can either change your first layer height (in the example below, I increased it from 0.25 to 0.30 mm), or use the ‘Shift’ option in Customizer, which will stick a square of the desired thickness to the bottom of the pyramid. This can also be used to enforce a solid bottom layer, which might help if you have problems with too little or too much adhesion.

This sharpener is designed for printing on a 3D printer. Angles of sharpening from 12 to 25 degrees on the side. After 3D printing, ream the holes with a drill 8mm. If you do not find a spring, print "spacer" file (instead of 2pcs "Springs_holder").

To make that thing you need:
1) 1pcs Laminated resin-bonded chipboard 400x200x16 mm;
2) 1pcs Stainless steel round bar 8mm L=700mm. On the one hand it needs make a thread M8x1.25 L= 30 mm;
3) 1pcs Stainless steel round bar 8mm L=120mm. On the one hand it needs make a thread M8x1.25 L= 20 mm;
4) 1pcs 8mm right hand female thread metric rod end SI8TK (for example
https://ru.aliexpress.com/item/SI8T-K-PHSA8-8/32679845372.html);
5) 1pcs Pressure spring inner diameter 12 mm, wire diameter from 1.5 to 2 mm;
6) 2pcs Neodymium block Magnet 20x20x5 mm;
7) 4pcs M4x20 Head pan screws + Nuts
8) 2pcs M6x20 Hex head cap screws + M6 Wing nuts
9) 8pcs Pan head Self-tapping screws DIN7981 st3.5 l=22 mm

if you need source files, you are welcome here: https://grabcad.com/library/knife-sharpener-4

This is a 2 part wedge, used to keep my oven steady. I installed these between the oven and the cupboards in order to stop the oven from wobbling when we walk past. The model is a 2 part print: Wedge A has a nut trap for an M5 nut sit in.
Wedge B has a slot for an M5 bolt to slide up and down in. Included is the OpenSCAD file for anyone to make adjustments to. The variables at the top of the file are self explanatory, because without the variables, these wedges would be useless to everyone else. I would love to see what else this model can be used for. These were printed on a RepRap Prusa i2, in Black PLA.

You will need a nut and bolt per wedge pair (I used M5 30mm long machine screws). The STL files uploaded here are for height of 14.5mm, in order to get the most out of the model please use the OpenSCAD file to customise some of the variables: Length, Width, Bolt Size (if different to M5),
Height - This was the most critical (The gap between my oven and cupboards). Uncomment each model at the bottom to export your STL. Play around and let me know how it goes. I've only done a few models in OpenSCAD (or at all), so go easy on me. Any feedback would be welcome. I printed with Black PLA 1.75mm, 0.24mm layer height, 40% Infill, active cooling, no support.

comments.text: Where is your eye protection? Not just for you but those in the room? Any laser that can burn can cause instant eye damage from little more than a reflection. It does not need to be a direct beam. Just looking at the laser operate as it is in this image could cause irreparable eye damage. At the very least you need a UV blocking curtain around the unit when it is operating. Or have enough safety glasses rated for the proper level of UV blockage for yourself and everyone else in the room rather they are viewing the process or not. I really wish people would learn laser safety before doing anything like this. Just because it is sold openly does not mean it is safe to use as is.
